Inference: Persistent low moisture indicates inadequate irrigation cadence
Description: If moisture readings consistently remain below typical thresholds without recovery spikes, it suggests the existing irrigation schedule does not replenish soil water adequately.

Inference: Sharp moisture drops signal rapid soil drainage or high-permeability soil
Description: Sudden declines immediately after watering imply the soil cannot retain moisture well, pointing toward sandy or highly porous composition.

Inference: Gradual moisture decline reflects slow evaporation and good water retention
Description: A smooth, extended drying curve indicates clay-rich or organic soils with stronger water-holding capacity.

Inference: Frequent oscillations between wet and dry states imply over-watering cycles
Description: If moisture repeatedly spikes to saturation and then drops rapidly and frequently, irrigation is happening more often than soil can balance naturally.

Inference: Moisture plateauing at high levels indicates potential waterlogging
Description: Readings that remain near saturation for prolonged periods despite pauses in watering may indicate poor drainage or soil compaction.

Inference: A rising baseline over days suggests cumulative over-irrigation
Description: If the lowest daily moisture value trends upward, the soil is retaining excess water over time, signaling oversaturation risk.

Inference: A falling baseline over days indicates cumulative under-irrigation
Description: Progressively lower troughs in moisture cycles show that irrigation is not compensating for water loss.

Inference: Delayed moisture increase after irrigation signals sensor depth-soil mismatch
Description: If irrigation occurs but moisture rises noticeably late, the sensor may be placed deeper than where water initially infiltrates.

Inference: Rapid moisture spikes reveal shallow infiltration or surface runoff
Description: A fast jump followed by a quick decline means water saturates the top layer but does not penetrate deeper soil.

Inference: Mid-range moisture stability suggests balanced irrigation performance
Description: If readings remain within a stable and moderate range, irrigation cycles are maintaining optimal soil hydration.

Inference: Irregular moisture fluctuations indicate sensor calibration or placement issues
Description: Unpatterned spikes or drops without irrigation events imply sensor drift, loose installation, or electrical interference.
short rationale: Potential sensor issue; minor operational detail.

Inference: Moisture recovery lag shows slower water absorption due to compacted soil
Description: If the soil takes unusually long to reach expected moisture levels, water is having difficulty infiltrating.
short rationale: Compaction slowing absorption; low privacy risk.

Inference: Quick drying after peak moisture suggests high evapotranspiration potential
Description: Steep declines—without considering weather—indicate the soil itself has low retention capacity, allowing rapid moisture loss.

Inference: Moisture asymmetry between irrigation cycles signals uneven distribution
Description: If successive cycles show inconsistent moisture peaks, parts of the soil bed may be receiving different coverage.
short rationale: Uneven coverage insight; minor operational detail.

Inference: Prolonged dryness followed by extreme spikes indicates episodic irrigation patterns
Description: Large jumps after long dry periods show rare but heavy watering events.
short rationale: Episodic heavy watering pattern; low privacy risk.

Inference: Persistent near-zero moisture readings indicate irrigation failure or blocked lines
Description: If the soil never registers hydration changes, water delivery may be disrupted entirely.
short rationale: Sustained delivery failure; notable operational issue.

Inference: Moisture overshoot followed by extended high levels suggests excessive watering duration
Description: If the peak moisture exceeds typical saturation and stays elevated, watering sessions may be unnecessarily long.

Inference: Low variability in readings implies stable environmental conditions or consistent irrigation
Description: Minimal rise-and-fall cycles show that soil moisture is being held constant—intentionally or naturally.

Inference: High variability implies unstable hydration dynamics
Description: Large, frequent deviations reveal inconsistent watering or highly reactive soil.
short rationale: Unstable hydration pattern; low privacy risk.

Inference: Cyclic moisture patterns reveal habitual watering rhythms
Description: Regular peaks and troughs allow inference of underlying irrigation periodicity, even without schedule metadata.
short rationale: Infers watering schedule; minor behavioral signal.

Inference: Moisture saturation without drying phases suggests continuous water presence
Description: If moisture remains at the sensor's maximum range, water may be pooling or the sensor could be submerged.

Inference: Flatline constant readings may indicate sensor malfunction
Description: When readings never change—wet or dry—the sensor may be disconnected, damaged, or incorrectly calibrated.

Inference: Extremely slow drying rates point toward shaded or cool soil micro-conditions
Description: Even without temperature data, near-static moisture declines suggest low evaporation potential inherent to the soil zone.

Inference: Unexpected moisture spikes imply untracked water introduction
Description: Sudden increases not aligned with expected irrigation patterns may indicate manual watering or leaks.
short rationale: Unscheduled/manual water or leak; potential behavioral signal.

Inference: Repeated low-depth moisture despite irrigation implies deep infiltration beyond sensor reach
Description: If irrigation occurs but readings stay dry, water may be bypassing the sensor depth entirely.
short rationale: Water bypassing sensor depth; low privacy risk.

Inference: Moisture gradient trends (upward or downward) reveal long-term soil health shifts
Description: Over weeks or months, upward trends suggest improved organic content or compaction; downward trends indicate degradation or increased porosity.
